page.title: 18A LOCAL HISTORY OF BUSBY
page.content: There is evidence of a{pre-Roman {settlement}on the west bank of the Cart near Overlee.The name 'Busby' is unusual for Scotland as it is a Saxon word.Early water powered{mills}were located on the east bank of the Cart in the 17th century.However by 1860 cotton weaving was abandoned and by 1900 the last mill closed.In spite of this the population grew with the opening of a{railway}making Busby only a half hour's journey from Glasgow.This made Busby popular with rich Glasgow merchants whose houses are now part of the Conservation Area.This means Busby has been a {'commuter'}village for over 100 years.The sites of the old mills still exist as industrial estates.Some of the old buildings such as Lower Mill have been renovated and are used today for offices and small factories.
